question_text:
Use suitable identities to find the following products:
(i) (x + 4)(x + 10)
(ii) (x + 8)(x – 10)
(iii) (3x + 4)(3x – 5)
(iv) (y² + 3/2)(y² – 3/2)
(v) (3 – 2x)(3 + 2x)
explanation:
(i) Recognize (x + 4)(x + 10) fits the identity (x + a)(x + b) = x² + (a + b)x + ab. Here, a = 4 and b = 10 so x² + (4+10)x + (4×10) = x² + 14x + 40.
(ii) For (x + 8)(x – 10), we again use (x + a)(x + b) with a = 8 and b = -10. Then, x² + (8 + (–10))x + (8×–10) = x² – 2x – 80.
(iii) In (3x + 4)(3x – 5), factor out 3 from the x term. Using the same identity with a = 4 and b = –5 (and noting the x coefficient 3 carries through): (3x)² + (4 + (–5))(3x) + (4×–5) = 9x² – 3x – 20.
(iv) Recognize (y² + 3/2)(y² – 3/2) is a difference of squares: (y²)² – (3/2)² = y⁴ – 9/4.
(v) (3 – 2x)(3 + 2x) is also a difference of squares: 3² – (2x)² = 9 – 4x².
topic: Algebraic Identities (Products and Difference of Squares)

question_text:
Evaluate the following products without multiplying directly:
(i) 103 × 107
(ii) 95 × 96
(iii) 104 × 96
explanation:
For (i), write 103 and 107 as (105 – 2) and (105 + 2) respectively. Then, using the identity (a – b)(a + b) = a² – b², we have: 105² – 2² = 11025 – 4 = 11021.
For (ii), express 95 and 96 as (100 – 5) and (100 – 4) respectively. Their product is 10000 – 100×(5+4) + (5×4) = 10000 – 900 + 20 = 9120.
For (iii), write 104 and 96 as (100 + 4) and (100 – 4). Then, (100)² – (4)² = 10000 – 16 = 9984.
topic: Algebraic Identities (Products using Difference of Squares)

question_text:
Factorise the following using appropriate identities:
(i) 9x² + 6xy + y²
(ii) 4y² – 4y + 1
(iii) x² – y²/100
explanation:
For (i), note that 9x² = (3x)², y² is already a square, and 6xy = 2⋅(3x)(y). Thus the expression is a perfect square: (3x + y)².
For (ii), 4y² = (2y)², 1 = 1², and –4y = –2⋅(2y)(1), so the expression factors as (2y – 1)².
For (iii), recognize x² – (y²/100) as a difference of squares where x² = x² and (y/10)² = y²/100. Hence, it factors as (x – y/10)(x + y/10).

question_text:
Expand each of the following, using suitable identities:
(i) (x + 2y + 4z)²
(ii) (2x – y + z)²
(iii) (–2x + 3y + 2z)²
(iv) (3a – 7b – c)²
(v) (–2x + 5y – 3z)²
(vi) [(1/4)a – (1/2)b + 1]²
correct_answer:
(i) x² + 4y² + 16z² + 4xy + 8xz + 16yz
(ii) 4x² + y² + z² – 4xy + 4xz – 2yz
(iii) 4x² + 9y² + 4z² – 12xy – 8xz + 12yz
(iv) 9a² + 49b² + c² – 42ab – 6ac + 14bc
(v) 4x² + 25y² + 9z² – 20xy + 12xz – 30yz
(vi) a²/16 + b²/4 + 1 + (–a·b/4) + (a/2) – b
explanation:
We use the extended identity for three terms: (x + y + z)² = x² + y² + z² + 2xy + 2xz + 2yz. For each part, identify the three terms and substitute:
(i) Let the terms be x, 2y and 4z. Then: x² + (2y)² + (4z)² + 2⋅x⋅2y + 2⋅x⋅4z + 2⋅2y⋅4z = x² + 4y² + 16z² + 4xy + 8xz + 16yz.
(ii) For (2x – y + z)², treat the terms as 2x, –y and z. Expanding gives: (2x)² + (–y)² + z² + 2(2x)(–y) + 2(2x)(z) + 2(–y)(z) = 4x² + y² + z² – 4xy + 4xz – 2yz.
(iii) Similarly, (–2x + 3y + 2z)² expands to 4x² + 9y² + 4z² + 2(–2x)(3y) + 2(–2x)(2z) + 2(3y)(2z) = 4x² + 9y² + 4z² – 12xy – 8xz + 12yz.
(iv) For (3a – 7b – c)², the expansion yields: (3a)² + (–7b)² + (–c)² + 2(3a)(–7b) + 2(3a)(–c) + 2(–7b)(–c) = 9a² + 49b² + c² – 42ab – 6ac + 14bc.
(v) (–2x + 5y – 3z)² expands as: (–2x)² + (5y)² + (–3z)² + 2(–2x)(5y) + 2(–2x)(–3z) + 2(5y)(–3z) = 4x² + 25y² + 9z² – 20xy + 12xz – 30yz.
(vi) For [(1/4)a – (1/2)b + 1]², square each term and add twice the products: ((1/4)a)² = a²/16, ((–1/2)b)² = b²/4, and 1² = 1. Plus, 2⋅(1/4)a⋅(–1/2)b = –a·b/4, 2⋅(1/4)a⋅1 = a/2, and 2⋅(–1/2)b⋅1 = –b. Hence, the expanded form is a²/16 + b²/4 + 1 – (a·b/4) + (a/2) – b.
topic: Expansion using Algebraic Identities (Trinomial Square Expansion)

explanation:
For (i), rewrite each term as a square and note the cross terms:
• 4x² = (2x)², 9y² = (3y)², 16z² = (4z)²
• 12xy = 2×(2x)(3y), –16xz = 2×(2x)(–4z), –24yz = 2×(3y)(–4z).
Thus, the expression is the expansion of (2x + 3y – 4z)².
For (ii), express the quadratic in a similar format:
• 2x², y², 8z² are squares and observe that –2√2xy = 2×(√2x)(–y) and –8xz = 2×(√2x)(–2√2z) while 4√2yz = 2×(–y)(–2√2z).
Thus, the perfect square is (√2 x – y – 2√2 z)².
topic: Factorisation using Algebraic Identities (Perfect Square Trinomials)

question_text:
Write the following cubes in expanded form:
(i) (2x + 1)³
(ii) (2a – 3b)³
(iii) [(3/2)x + 1]³
(iv) [x – (2/3)y]³
explanation:
For cube expansions, we use the identities:
• (x + y)³ = x³ + y³ + 3xy(x + y) and
• (x – y)³ = x³ – y³ – 3xy(x – y).
(i) (2x + 1)³: Here x = 2x and y = 1. So, (2x)³ = 8x³, 1³ = 1, and 3(2x)(1)(2x + 1) = 6x(2x + 1) = 12x² + 6x.
Thus, 8x³ + 12x² + 6x + 1.
(ii) (2a – 3b)³: View it as (2a)³ – (3b)³ – 3(2a)(3b)(2a – 3b) = 8a³ – 27b³ – 18ab(2a – 3b) = 8a³ – 27b³ – 36a²b + 54ab².
(iii) [(3/2)x + 1]³: ( (3/2)x )³ = (27/8)x³, 1³ = 1, and 3×(3/2)x×1×((3/2)x + 1) = (9/2)x((3/2)x + 1) which expands to (27/4)x² + (9/2)x. Adding gives (27/8)x³ + (27/4)x² + (9/2)x + 1.
(iv) [x – (2/3)y]³: Using the identity for (x – y)³ with y replaced by (2/3)y:
 x³ – (2/3 y)³ – 3x(2/3 y)(x – (2/3)y).
Calculate each term: (2/3 y)³ = (8/27)y³, and 3x(2/3 y) = 2xy. Thus, the expansion is x³ – (8/27)y³ – 2xy(x – (2/3)y) = x³ – (8/27)y³ – 2x²y + (4/3)xy².

Factorise each of the following:
(i) 8a³ + b³ + 12a²b + 6ab²
(ii) 8a³ – b³ – 12a²b + 6ab²
(iii) 27 – 125a³ – 135a + 225a²
(iv) 64a³ – 27b³ – 144a²b + 108ab²
(v) 27p³ – 1/216 – (9/2)p² + (1/4)p
explanation:
Each expression is structured as a perfect cube:
(i) Write 8a³ as (2a)³ and note that 12a²b = 3(2a)²b and 6ab² = 3(2a)b² with b³ remaining. Hence, the sum is (2a + b)³.
(ii) Similarly, 8a³ – b³ – 12a²b + 6ab² equals (2a – b)³ when using the cube expansion formula for a difference.
(iii) Rearranging 27 – 125a³ – 135a + 225a² in descending powers as –125a³ + 225a² – 135a + 27, notice it matches the expansion of (3 – 5a)³.
(iv) Express 64a³ as (4a)³ and 27b³ as (3b)³; the remaining terms match the expansion of (4a – 3b)³.
(v) Write 27p³ as (3p)³ and 1/216 as (1/6)³. The middle terms –(9/2)p² and (1/4)p match the expansion of (3p – 1/6)³.

question_text:
Verify:
(i) x³ + y³ = (x + y)(x² – xy + y²)
(ii) x³ – y³ = (x – y)(x² + xy + y²)
correct_answer:
For (i): Multiply (x + y)(x² – xy + y²) to get x³ + y³. 
For (ii): Multiply (x – y)(x² + xy + y²) to get x³ – y³.
explanation:
To verify (i), expand (x + y)(x² – xy + y²):
 x·x² = x³, x·(–xy) = –x²y, x·y² = xy²;
 y·x² = x²y, y·(–xy) = –xy², y·y² = y³.
Combining like terms gives x³ + y³. 
Similarly for (ii), expanding (x – y)(x² + xy + y²) gives x³ – y³.
topic: Algebraic Identities (Sum and Difference of Cubes)

explanation:
For (i), note that 27y³ = (3y)³ and 125z³ = (5z)³. Applying the sum of cubes identity: a³ + b³ = (a + b)(a² – ab + b²) with a = 3y and b = 5z gives (3y + 5z)(9y² – 15yz + 25z²).
For (ii), 64m³ = (4m)³ and 343n³ = (7n)³. Using the difference of cubes identity: a³ – b³ = (a – b)(a² + ab + b²) with a = 4m and b = 7n yields (4m – 7n)(16m² + 28mn + 49n²).

Recognize that 27x³ can be written as (3x)³. The expression then is in the form a³ + y³ + z³ – 3a·y·z with a = 3x. By Identity VIII, we have a³ + y³ + z³ – 3ayz = (a + y + z)(a² + y² + z² – ay – az – yz). Substituting a = 3x gives the factorisation: (3x + y + z)(9x² + y² + z² – 3xy – 3xz – yz).

question_text: Verify that x³ + y³ + z³ – 3xyz = (1/2)(x + y + z)[(x – y)² + (y – z)² + (z – x)²]
correct_answer: By expanding (1/2)(x + y + z)[(x – y)² + (y – z)² + (z – x)²] and simplifying, one obtains x³ + y³ + z³ – 3xyz.
explanation:
Begin by expanding each squared term:
• (x – y)² = x² – 2xy + y²
• (y – z)² = y² – 2yz + z²
• (z – x)² = z² – 2zx + x²
Summing these gives: 2x² + 2y² + 2z² – 2xy – 2yz – 2zx. Dividing by 2 yields x² + y² + z² – xy – yz – zx.
Multiplying by (x + y + z) leads to (x + y + z)(x² + y² + z² – xy – yz – zx). Expanding and then simplifying the resulting terms will show that it equals x³ + y³ + z³ – 3xyz.

question_text: If x + y + z = 0, show that x³ + y³ + z³ = 3xyz.
correct_answer: Under the condition x + y + z = 0, the identity x³ + y³ + z³ – 3xyz = (x + y + z)(x² + y² + z² – xy – yz – zx) implies that x³ + y³ + z³ – 3xyz = 0. Therefore, x³ + y³ + z³ = 3xyz.
explanation: Recall the identity: x³ + y³ + z³ – 3xyz = (x + y + z)(x² + y² + z² – xy – yz – zx). When x + y + z = 0, the entire right-hand side becomes 0, and hence x³ + y³ + z³ = 3xyz.

question_text:
Without actually calculating the cubes, find the value of each of the following:
(i) (–12)³ + (7)³ + (5)³
(ii) (28)³ + (–15)³ + (–13)³
explanation:
Notice that in each case, the sum of the numbers is zero:
(i) –12 + 7 + 5 = 0, so by the identity, x³ + y³ + z³ = 3xyz. Here, 3 × (–12) × 7 × 5 = 3 × (–420) = –1260.
(ii) 28 + (–15) + (–13) = 0, so 3 × 28 × (–15) × (–13) = 3 × 5460 = 16380.

question_text:
Give possible expressions for the length and breadth of each of the following rectangles, whose areas are given:
Area 1: 25a² – 35a + 12
Area 2: 35y² + 13y – 12
correct_answer:
For Area 1: Factorise 25a² – 35a + 12 as (5a – 3)(5a – 4). Hence, one possible set of dimensions is 5a – 3 and 5a – 4.
For Area 2: Factorise 35y² + 13y – 12 as (5y + 4)(7y – 3). So, the dimensions can be 5y + 4 and 7y – 3.
explanation:
For Area 1, we look for factors of 25a² – 35a + 12. Finding that (5a – 3)(5a – 4) multiplies to give the original expression (since 5a×5a = 25a², –3×–4 = 12, and the middle term –(15a + 20a) = –35a).
For Area 2, we need two numbers whose product is 35 × (–12) = –420 and whose sum is 13. The numbers 28 and –15 work because 28 + (–15) = 13. Rewriting, 35y² + 28y – 15y – 12 factors by grouping as (5y + 4)(7y – 3).

question_text:
What are the possible expressions for the dimensions of the cuboids whose volumes are given below?
Volume 1: 3x² – 12x
Volume 2: 12ky² + 8ky – 20k
correct_answer:
Volume 1: Factorise 3x² – 12x = 3x(x – 4). One may take the dimensions as 3x, (x – 4), and 1.
Volume 2: Factorise 12ky² + 8ky – 20k = 4k(3y² + 2y – 5). The quadratic factors as (3y + 5)(y – 1) (since 3y² + 2y – 5 = (3y + 5)(y – 1)). Thus, the dimensions can be taken as 4k, 3y + 5, and y – 1.
explanation:
For Volume 1, factor out the common term: 3x² – 12x = 3x(x – 4). Interpreting the volume as the product of three dimensions, one can choose the factors as 3x, (x – 4), and 1 (if a third dimension is not specified, 1 is assumed).
For Volume 2, factor out 4k first to get 4k(3y² + 2y – 5). Next, factor the quadratic 3y² + 2y – 5. Using splitting of the middle term, we find that it factors as (3y + 5)(y – 1). Thus, one valid set of dimensions is 4k, 3y + 5, and y – 1.
